questions.question: A 40-year-old woman with diabetes presents with worsening proteinuria. Her urine dipstick shows 3+ protein. A subsequent 24-hour urine collection was done, and possible glomerular disease was suspected. What is the estimated protein quantity for this condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) 2 g Explanation: In patients with possible glomerular disease, Urine dipstick shows 2+ to 3+ proteinuria, with a significant level of > 1 g of protein in 24 hours. Urine Dipstick test Significance It is a rapid and cost-effective tool for screening and monitoring various urinary abnormalities, aiding in the early detection of kidney and systemic diseases. Disadvantages Paraproteins (+ve charged protein) like Bence Jones proteins are missed in dipstick. The dipstick primarily detects albumin (a - ve charged protein), the most common urine protein, and may also identify other proteins, but in smaller amounts. Results can be affected by factors such as urine pH, concentration, and temperature , leading to inconsistent readings. Interpretation Comparing the colour changes on each reagent pad to the provided colour chart on the dipstick packaging helps in assessing parameters like Proteins Glucose Ketones Blood pH Nitrites Leukocyte Esterase urine dipstick result " data-author="Hxa098020" data-hash="8449" data-license="CC BY-SA 4.0" data-source="https://commons.wikim edia.org/wiki/File:Visually_read_a_urine_test_strip_by_comparing_it_with_the_color_key_provided_by_the_ma nufacturer._Color_chart_from_Urinox-10_urine_test_strips_by_Diagnox_is_shown_in_this_image.jpg" data-tags="" height="278" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/RpDGfX54KTEn9wBhlIGy1744281541.png" width="268" /> Normal range of Proteinuria Normal proteinuria in adults is <150mg/day Glomerular Proteinuria is <30mg/day Proteins from tubules are around 120 mg/day (Tamm Horsfall proteins/Uromodulin) Values of Proteinuria Dipstick Reading PCR Significance nil < 25 mg/mmol Normal nil 25 - 50 mg/mmol Moderate albuminuria 1+ to 2+ 50 - 100 mg/mmol Positive dipstick 2+ to 3+ 100 - 350 mg/mmol Possible glomerular disease, i.e.> 1g protein in a day 3+ to 4+ > 350 mg/mmol Nephrotic range, i.e. > 3.5 g protein in a day

questions.question: A 62-year-old man presents with fatigue, weight loss, and recurrent infections. Laboratory tests reveal anaemia and a serum immunofixation shows a monoclonal band. Which of the following tests helps identify proteinuria in this condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Urine electrophoresis Explanation: This case is consistent with multiple myeloma, with the detection of a monoclonal band on serum immunofixation indicating the presence of paraproteins. Urine electrophoresis is the most effective method to identify paraproteins in the urine. Serum protein electrophoresis > Urinary Protein Electrophoresis: Shows the presence of M-Spike (Monoclonal Antibodies). Electrophoresis - Normal Electrophoresis - Multiple Myeloma Paraproteins: Definition: Paraproteins, also known as monoclonal proteins , are abnormal immunoglobulins produced by a clone of plasma cells. Their excess production, often associated with haematological disorders like multiple myeloma, leads to their detection in blood and urine. Seen in: Multiple Myeloma (Bence-Jones proteins) Monoclonal gammopathy of uncertain signi I cance (MGUS) Waldenström macroglobulinemia Lymphoplasmacytic Lymphoma Investigation of choice: 24-hour urine protein electrophoresis and Immunofixation. It helps in identifying excess free light chains in urine (paraprotein) 24-Hour Urine protein quantification (Option A) : Although this test measures total protein excretion, it may miss intermittent excretion of paraproteins and does not differentiate between types of proteins present. Urine Dipstick (Option B) is less sensitive in detecting positively charged proteins like paraproteins and can show false negative proteinuria; hence, it is not preferred in these conditions. Urine microscopy (Option C) focuses on examining cells, casts, and crystals in the urine rather than quantifying or identifying specific proteins, which is not useful in this condition.

questions.question: A 45-year-old man presents with oedema, fatigue and foamy urine. Laboratory tests show Urine dipstick: 2+ for protein Urine albumin: 100 mg/d Based on his clinical presentation and lab findings, what renal pathology should be suspected?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Early stages of diabetes mellitus Explanation: The lab results indicate moderately increased albuminuria, which may indicate early stages of diabetes mellitus , while other conditions are associated with severely increased albuminuria. Type of Albuminuria Moderately increased Severely increased Albumin Excreted 30–300 mg/d 300–3500 mg/d Causes Early stages of DM (Option D) Early HTN Early stages of glomerulonephritis Congestive heart failure (Option B) Fever Exercise Diabetes Mellitus HTN Multiple Myeloma (Option C) Monoclonal Gammopathy of Undetermined Significance (MGUS) Severe Glomerulonephritis (Option A) Orthostatic proteinuria Intermittent proteinuria Microalbuminuria and Macroalbuminuria were the previously used terms for Moderately increased and Severely increased albuminuria, respectively. Albumin Excretion Rate (AER) is a measure of the amount of albumin excreted in urine over a specified period . AER = urine albumin/urine creatinine (mg/gm) Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Volume I, Page 336

questions.question: A 10-year-old boy presents to the clinic with complaints of generalised oedema, significant fatigue, and an increased weight over the past month; he mentions that he has recently noticed his urine appearing foamy. Urine Dipstick: 4+ for protein 24-Hour urine Protein: 5000 mg Serum Creatinine: 1.1 mg/dL What is the most likely underlying cause, considering these lab parameters?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Lipoid nephrosis Explanation: The labs show a nephrotic range of proteinuria, i.e., >3.5 g over 24 hours, and proteinuria of 3+ to 4+ in Dipstick analysis. Considering the patient's age, the more likely cause of Nephrotic changes can be Lipoid nephrosis , also called minimal change disease, which involves reversible damage to podocytes in the glomerulus. It is commonly observed in children but can also occur, though rarely, in adults. Causes of Nephrotic range Proteinuria Diabetic nephropathy Minimal change disease Membranous glomerulopathy IgA nephropathy Amyloidosis Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) Diabetic Nephropathy (Option A) is unlikely in this scenario because it is rare in children. Additionally, a significant history of diabetes mellitus is necessary for the development of diabetic nephropathy. IgA nephropathy (Option B) is caused by an abnormal immune response following infection, resulting in IgA antibody deposition in the glomeruli. This leads to hematuria and proteinuria and in severe cases, can progress to nephrotic syndrome. Membranous nephropathy (Option C) is rare in children but is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in adults . It is often idiopathic (primary) but can also be secondary to infections, cancer, certain drugs (e.g., NSAIDs), autoimmune diseases, or metal poisoning.d Disease Associations Serologic Tests Minimal Change Allergy, atopy, NSAIDs, Hodgkin’s None Focal Sclerosing Glomerulosclerosis African Americans, HIV, Heroin HIV Ab Membranous Drugs: gold, penicillamine, NSAIDs, Lupus Nephritis, Malignancy: breast, lung, GI Hep B surface antigen, Hep C antibody, Anti-DNA Ab Membranoproliferative GN Type I C4 Nephritic factor C3 ↓ , C4 ↓ Membranoproliferative GN Type II C3 Nephritic factor C3 ↓ , C4 normal Cryoglobulinemic MPGN Hepatitis C Anti-HCV antibody, rheumatoid factor, C3 ↓ , C4 ↓ , CH 50 ↓ Amyloidosis Myeloma, Rheumatoid arthritis, bronchiectasis, Crohn’s disease, FMF SPEP, UPEP Diabetic Nephropathy Other diabetic microangiopathy None Reference: Davidson’s Principles and Practice of Medicine, 24th Edition, Page 398, 400, Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Volume I, Page 336.

questions.question: A 30-year-old male, recovering post-operatively after ACL surgery, develops a fever, nausea, and cough. A urine dipstick reveals trace proteinuria. He has no history of hypertension or diabetes. What is the most likely cause of his proteinuria?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Functional proteinuria Explanation: In this case, the most likely cause of proteinuria is functional proteinuria or transient proteinuria, which occurs in acute stressors like fever, urinary tract infection, surgery, exercise, or emotional stress. In this post-operative patient with a recent fever and no history of hypertension or diabetes, or renal pathology, functional proteinuria is the most probable cause. It is typically transient and mild, often resolving with the resolution of the stressor. Type of Proteinuria Causes Transient Fever, Stress, Dehydration, Cold exposure Orthostatic Subtle glomerular abnormality, Exaggerated hemodynamic response Persistent Diabetes, Lupus, Renal disease Post-renal UTIs, Nephrolithiasis Tubular Wilson Disease, Cystinosis, Nephrotoxic medicines, Interstitial nephritis, Acute Tubular Necrosis (ATN) Glomerular Glomerular basement membrane damage, Minimal change disease, IgA Nephropathy Overflow Multiple myeloma, Rhabdomyolysis Tubular proteinuria (Option A) occurs due to impaired reabsorption of low-molecular-weight proteins by damaged renal tubules, indicating tubular dysfunction. It is seen in conditions like acute tubular necrosis , tubulointerstitial nephritis , and certain genetic disorders affecting the proximal tubules. Glomerular Proteinuria (Option B) involves the excretion of high-molecular-weight proteins, primarily albumin, due to damage or dysfunction of the glomerular filtration barrier. It is commonly associated with conditions like nephrotic syndrome, glomerulonephritis, and immune interstitial nephritis. Overload proteinuria (Option C) results from an excessive amount of proteins in the bloodstream that overwhelms the kidneys' ability to reabsorb them, leading to their excretion without direct renal damage. It is commonly seen in conditions like multiple myeloma, hemoglobinuria, and myoglobinuria. Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Volume I, Page 2356, 2282, 2281 Davidson’s Principles and Practice of Medicine, 24th Edition, Page 393, 394. https://www.uptodate.com/contents/assessment-of -urinary-protein-excretion-and-evaluation-of-isolated-non-nephrotic-proteinuria-in-adults?search=transient%20pr oteinuria&source=search_result&selectedTitle=1%7E16&usage_type=default&display_rank=1#H13

questions.question: A 45-year-old female presents with dysuria, increased urinary frequency, and urgency. Laboratory tests show 6 red blood cells and 20 pus cells/HPF with no visible discolouration. She was treated for a UTI, and later, a couple of repeat urinalysis in consecutive weeks revealed the same RBC count without any discoloration. Which of the following best describes this finding?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Significant hematuria Explanation: Significant hematuria (Option A) It is defined as the presence of more than 3 RBCs/HPF in a centrifuged specimen at an interval of 1 week (or) More than 100 RBCs/HPF in a single analysis (or) Presence of gross hematuria (Gross hematuria can be significant hematuria, but not all significant hematuria is gross hematuria). Normal Finding (Option A) Is the presence of less than 3 RBCs/HPF Isolated hematuria Presence of hematuria alone without any other casts, cells or proteinuria. Seen in urinary tract bleeding. Gross Hematuria (Option C) Presence of red blood cells in the urine that is visible to the naked eye causes the urine to appear red, brown or pink. Examples: Benign prostate hyperplasia, Kidney stones False positive hematuria Dipstick can be found positive for hematuria in the case of myoglobinuria. Examples: Rhabdomyolysis Medications can cause hematuria or urinary discoloration due to pseudohematuria (ie, red, pink, or brown urine discoloration), kidney damage, nephrolithiasis or urolithiasis, or hemorrhagic cystitis. Medications that can lead to hematuria include (Option D): Allopurinol Blood thinners, such as warfarin or antiplatelet drugs Cephalosporins Hydralazine Nitrofurantoin Penicillin Rifampin Sulfa drugs Drug induced hematuria often resolves when the offending drug is discontinued, which is not noted in this scenario. Moreover, the patient experienced hematuria even before receiving any medications, making this an unlikely option. Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Volume I, Page 337.

questions.question: A 35-year-old male presents to the emergency department with red urine (as shown below) for two days and mild flank pain. He has no prior urinary issues and reports no pain or trauma. Urine was sent for repeat analysis, and an ultrasound was recommended. What is the most common cause of hematuria in this case?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Nephrolithiasis Explanation: The clinical presentation of flank pain and hematuria suggests a diagnosis of Nephrolithiasis, which can result in Hematuria due to obstruction, potentially leading to kidney injury. Hematuria is defined as more than 5 RBC per HPF (high power fields) three times in a centrifuged specimen at an interval of one week (or more than 100 RBC per HPF in a single sample). Normally, the number of red blood cells (RBCs) in urine is less than 3 RBCs per high-power field (HPF). Causes of Hematuria Nephrolithiasis (Most common in adults) Trauma Renal tumour Glomerular diseases (like glomerulonephritis, small-vessel vasculitis, SLE (Systemic lupus erythematosus), etc.) Polyarteritis nodosa

questions.question: A 28-year-old female presents to her primary care physician with swelling in her legs and around her eyes that has worsened over the past two weeks. She reports feeling fatigued and experiencing foamy urine. Urinalysis reveals findings, as shown in the image below. Which of the following conditions exhibits similar urine findings?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Fabry’s disease Explanation: The scenario describes a case of Nephrotic syndrome , and the image depicts a Maltese Cross Appearance , which is also a characteristic feature observed in the urine analysis of Fabry's disease. Oval fat bodies and birefringent glycolipid globules, observed under polarised light, form specific shapes referred to as the Maltese cross appearance. Nephrotic syndrome It is characterised by significant proteinuria (> 3.5 g/24 hrs), hypoalbuminemia, and oedema resulting from injury to the podocytes. Diseases like minimal change disease, membranous nephropathy, amyloid, diabetic nephropathy, and glomerulosclerosis can cause it. Fabry’s disease (Option C) A lysosomal storage disorder is caused by a mutation in the GLA gene, which results in a deficiency of the enzyme alpha-galactosidase A. Clinical features include neurological symptoms (such as pain in the extremities), dermatological manifestations (including hypohidrosis and angiokeratomas), and cerebrovascular complications (affecting the kidneys, heart, and central nervous system). diabetic patient. Clinical Kidney Journal. 2. 405-407. 10.1093/ndtplus/sfp062. " data-hash="8464" data-license="CC BY-NC 4.0" data-source="https://www.researchgate.net/figure/Urinary-sedi ment-analysis-of-patient-with-a-nephrotic-syndrome-by-A-phase-contrast_fig2_275289378" data-tags="" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/zwz2lD5nEVrZhsckyWNv1744282584.png" /> Alport disease (Option A) It is an X-linked recessive disorder resulting from the deletion of the COL4A5 gene (type IV collagen) . It is

questions.question: A 32-year-old female visits her primary care physician for a routine check-up. She feels well and has no specific concerns. Routine investigations reveal her urinalysis shows a specific gravity of 1.032. What is the most likely cause of this finding?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Dehydration Explanation: Specific gravity can be elevated due to dehydration, whereas psychogenic polydipsia, diabetes insipidus, and overhydration result in diluted urine, leading to a decrease in specific gravity. It is the measure of the concentration of solutes in the urine compared to pure water. Normal range: Specific gravity: 1.020-1.030 Urine osmolality: 100 - 900 mOsm/kg Increased levels of specific gravity Conditions leading to volume depletion, like dehydration (Option A) (Inadequate fluid intake, diarrhoea, burns, vomiting), heart failure, etc. Decreased levels of specific gravity Conditions leading to overhydration, fluid retention or urine dilution, like renal tubular dysfunction (Option D) , diabetes insipidus (Option C) , psychogenic polydipsia (Option B) , etc. Significance: Isosthenuria (isosmotic with plasma): Inability to concentrate the urine, as observed in chronic tubulointerstitial disease and sickle cell anaemia. Specific gravity differentiates between causes of AKI (acute kidney injury): Pre-renal: Specific gravity increases Renal: Specific gravity decreases Reference: Textbook of Biochemistry, by D.M. Vasudevan, 7th Edition, Page 364.

questions.question: A 55-year-old male with chronic kidney disease and recurrent renal stones visits the clinic for routine monitoring. He reports occasional flank pain and increased urinary frequency. Urinalysis shows cloudy urine with a pH of 9.0 and a specific gravity of 1.005. Which of the following conditions can lead to low urine pH?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) High protein diet Explanation: A high-protein diet can result in acidic urine (low urine pH). Urine pH: Normal range: 4-4.5 Significance: Provide diagnostic information in the assessment of renal tubular acidosis (RTA): Alkaline urine (pH>5.5) In case of ATN (acute tubular necrosis): Alkaline urine (high pH). Acidic urine (low pH) Alkaline urine (high pH) High protein diet (Option D) Starvation or fasting Dehydration Diabetic ketoacidosis Nephrolithiasis Metabolic acidosis Renal tubular acidosis type 2 (Type 2 RTA) Renal tubular acidosis type 4 (Type 4 RTA) Vegetarian diet (Option A) Low protein diet Chronic kidney disease (CKD) Urinary tract infections (Option B) Renal tubular acidosis type 1 (Type 1 RTA) (Option C) Metabolic alkalosis

questions.question: A 14-year-old boy with beta-thalassemia major, diagnosed at six months and dependent on regular blood transfusions, is brought in by his parents for a routine follow-up. Lab results show significantly elevated serum ferritin levels. The pediatrician starts treatment with Deferoxamine. What colour will his urine likely be?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Pink colour Explanation: Desferrioxamine imparts a pink colour to the urine. This phenomenon, known as vin rosé urine, occurs due to the iron-chelating properties of deferoxamine, which binds to iron and forms a compound that colours the urine pinkish-red. Colour of urine in different conditions Urine colour Condition Pale yellow (amber-yellow or straw-coloured) Normal urine Pink (Option C) Deferoxamine Serratia Mascarenes (Pink diaper syndrome) Black (Option B) Paroxysmal cold Haemoglobinuria (PCH) Paroxysmal nocturnal Haemoglobinuria (PNH) Black (on air exposure) Alkaptonuria (can be prevented by vitamin C) Red urine (Option A) Clofazimine Porphyria Myoglobinuria Beetroot ingestion Cola colour (Option D) Glomerulonephritis (Hematuria) Yellow Jaundice (bilirubinuria) B-complex intake Orange Rifampicin Milky Chyluria (lymphatic fluid in urine) Cloudy or Opalascent Pyuria (presence of pus cells) Reference: Textbook of Biochemistry, by D.M. Vasudevan, 7th Edition, Page 364.

questions.question: A 29-year-old female presents to the emergency department with fever, chills, frequent urination, and severe right flank pain. Urinalysis reveals findings, as shown in the image. What is the most likely cause of her condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Acute pyelonephritis Explanation: The symptoms suggest a urinary tract infection, and the image displaying WBC casts supports a diagnosis of Acute pyelonephritis. Urine casts Associated conditions Hyaline cast It is observed in healthy individuals and is composed of Tamm-Horsfall protein (produced by the kidney). RBC cast Acute glomerulonephritis (Option A) IgA nephropathy WBC cast Acute pyelonephritis (Option B) Chronic pyelonephritis Acute interstitial nephritis Muddy brown cast (renal tubular epithelial cast) Acute tubular necrosis (Option C) Broad casts Chronic kidney disease (CKD) (diabetic nephropathy) (Option D) Granular waxy cast waxy cast" data-author="Chu-Su, Yu & Shukuya, Kenichi & Yokoyama, Takashi & Lin, W.-C & Chiang, Chih-Kang & Lin, Chii-Wann. (2017). Enhancing the Detection of Dysmorphic Red Blood Cells and Renal Tubular Epithelial Cells with a Modified Urinalysis Protocol. Scientific Reports. 7. 40521. 10.1038/srep40521.
